values.alignmentText: Canada's .NET market is solid in Toronto, Montreal, and Vancouver; visa timelines exist, but steady openings and remote options help Trey.
Canada summers bring occasional wildfire smoke and urban pollution. Check air-quality alerts and use portable filters on smoky days.
Canada's secular public life supports raising kids with little religious pressure. Atheism is widely accepted, with faith communities visible.
Canada’s robust institutions and an independent judiciary protect rights in Ottawa. Free media keeps backsliding risk low.
Canada's big banks and Interac support smooth payments with solid protections. New arrivals may face initial account paperwork, but digital banking helps.
Canadian beaches are cool-water; casual beach days are rare for young kids, so we plan summer trips to inland lakes or warmer coasts.
Canada's major cities like Toronto, Montreal, and Vancouver host board game nights and family-friendly shops; Trey will find a welcoming tabletop scene.
Canada offers public healthcare and provincial childcare subsidies; costs and waitlists vary by province, so proactive planning and local networks help.
Canada cities offer parks, libraries, and family programs. Long winters require indoor spaces; seek family-friendly neighborhoods and accessible childcare.
Canada provides the Canada Child Benefit and long parental leave. Expanded $10/day childcare helps, though waitlists vary by province.
Temporary residents in Canada may access some subsidized childcare and parental leave, but provincial eligibility checks and waiting lists apply.
Canada has strong hockey/outdoor sports culture and many clubs; board games and climbing exist but often need local groups.
Canada (CA) is generally welcoming; Trey and Sarah can build social ties through schools, clubs, and local groups.
Canada has clear digital portals and predictable filings. Expect periodic check-ins, but overall navigable for a family pursuing visas.
Toronto and Vancouver housing and groceries stretch a mid-six-figure tech income; consider secondary metros or suburbs.
Canada fully permits dual citizenship with the US. Trey and Sarah can retain US passports and their kids can gain Canadian rights with minimal friction.
Canada's economy is solid with low unemployment and diversified industries; social programs cushion shocks for families pursuing entrepreneurship.
Canada's social-market economy funds healthcare and childcare and backs startups with grants, balancing innovation with governance for progressive capitalism.
Canada's public schools deliver strong outcomes with broad access. Bilingual (French immersion) options align with the family's goals and robust early education.
Canada offers LMIA/Global Talent Stream sponsorship for tech roles; Trey would need standout credentials and patient timelines.
Canada's strong water standards and vast national parks suit outdoors lovers; minor Alberta oil sands impacts temper otherwise excellent environmental quality.
In Canada, dual tech incomes face about 30% tax with strong public services; a balanced burden for a startup family.
Canada fall swings between mild days and cool evenings. Prairie regions may see early frosts, so layer clothing for school and outings.
Canada's universal healthcare and parental leave support families. Many neighborhoods offer kid-friendly spaces, clubs, and safe public areas.
Canada's programs let spouses and dependent children join. Your two kids and both adults can travel together under family sponsorship.
Canada provides universal healthcare and strong parental benefits; child benefits are indexed to inflation, though childcare access varies by province.
Canada offers strong parental leave and child benefits. Subsidies vary by province and income caps apply.
Canada visa families receive partial benefits: health coverage after a residency wait; most cash benefits require permanent status, leaving gaps.
Canada's urban centers like Toronto and Vancouver are diverse and body-positive. This suits Sarah's casual tech style with broad fashion freedom.

Canada generally supports diverse femininity expressions, especially in urban areas. This aligns with Sarah's career-family balance and low-bias expectations.
Canada's game scene is strong in Montreal and Vancouver with many mid-to-large studios and solid hiring; good grant support for Trey.
Montreal and Vancouver’s established studios in Canada move quickly; most roles close in 6–8 weeks thanks to strong pipelines and visa programs.
Canada studios align with global medians after cost-of-living adjustments. Family-friendly benefits and universal healthcare improve overall value in CA.

Hybrid/remote roles are standard across established Canadian studios (Toronto/Vancouver/Montreal) with formal policies that support family-friendly schedules.
Canada offers legal recognition and inclusive healthcare for gender-diverse families; urban areas are welcoming, with rural areas lagging slightly.
Canada provides strong gender rights with active enforcement; equal pay, reproductive rights, and parental leave are well protected for families like this.
Canada strongly supports shared parenting and equality; urban areas are progressive, though some rural norms linger.
Canada offers universal healthcare and strong schools, but temporary residents face visa renewals and provincial health wait periods; plan for coverage gaps.
Canada faces stronger wildfire seasons and heat waves. Coastal storms and flooding risk in Atlantic provinces require ongoing planning.
In Canada, universal coverage supports pediatric care; expect occasional specialist waits—plan routine visits early for the kids.
Canada: temporary residents face provincial waiting periods. Private insurance bridges coverage for kids.
Canada's public universities plus RESP grants keep post-secondary affordable for the kids. Living costs in Canada still require budgeting.
Canada: international students pay higher tuition and limited government aid. University scholarships and private loans are the main funding avenues.

Canada public K-12 access for visa holders is allowed but requires proof of residence and some paperwork; ESL supports are available.
Canada-wide English use is strong; federal documents are bilingual, easing Trey's work and daily life in urban Canada, including Montreal.
Canada offers strong LGBTQ+ protections and vibrant Pride in major cities (Toronto, Vancouver); rural areas may be more conservative.
In Canada (CA), Marxism is niche but openly discussed; progressive households like Trey can engage socialist ideas in pluralistic policy debates.
Canada's dads are increasingly involved in schools and caregiving. Trey can model evolving, emotionally open masculinity in Canada.

Canada's urban hubs offer gigabit fiber and reliable services; rural broadband gaps may affect Trey’s game latency.
Canada's mountains, boreal forests, and coastlines offer stunning family-friendly weekends. Trails are well-maintained, with seasonal beauty year-round.

Canada offers abundant nature within an hour of most urban centers. Parks, lakes, and urban trails suit Trey's hobbies and the kids' need for green space.
Canada's major cities offer vibrant live music and festivals. Many venues provide family-friendly options, though some late shows require planning.
Canada's nightlife is moderate; in major cities like Toronto and Montreal, early closing times keep evenings family-friendly.
Strong Canadian game dev scene across Toronto, Montreal, and Vancouver with regular meetups, jams, and mentorship for newcomers.
Canada's strong game-scene hubs (Montreal, Toronto) host notable studios like Ubisoft Montreal, EA Motive, Behaviour; great for collaborations.

Canada startup pay sits near global medians after cost of living; equity meaningful, with grants and visas aiding founders in Toronto, Montréal, Vancouver.
In Canada, English is widely used for startup ops; in Quebec, French supports hiring, compliance, and community outreach.
Canada startups broadly favor hybrid work with mature remote tooling. For our family, remote or hybrid options with periodic onsite meets in Toronto/Vancouver fit well.
Canada's mid-sized cities like Ottawa and Halifax offer the calm pace Sarah seeks. Toronto's hustle remains manageable with remote work.
Canada offers empathetic parenting support; schools partner with families and parental leave is normal, allowing hockey or coding clubs with little judgment.
Canada offers citizenship after 3 years of permanent residency within 5 years, with language tests. Dual citizenship is allowed for the whole family.
Canada's strong institutions and universal healthcare keep graft rare; active watchdogs support transparent governance for families.
Canada's federal parliamentary system and Charter rights fit your progressive values; it's a stable, participatory democracy.

Canada provides subsidies and public programs, but urban waitlists persist; early enrollment helps, with bilingual options in major cities.
Canada has strong bilingual public schools; private options exist but vary in quality and cost, so private education remains optional.
Canada's universal healthcare, LGBTQ+ rights, and climate action align with Trey and Sarah's progressive values; provincial politics vary.
Canada's messaging emphasizes inclusive wellbeing and accuracy. Plural, independent media in Toronto, Montreal, and Vancouver offer diverse viewpoints.
Canada's pluralistic media mix, including public broadcasters and independent outlets, keeps coverage balanced. Spin is occasional and debunked by watchdogs, matching your family's values.
Canada's major cities have reliable transit (Toronto, Vancouver). Suburbs and smaller towns still rely on cars.
Canada's secular Charter framework supports raising the boys; religion shapes culture but policy remains evidence-based and pluralistic.
Canada's tech hubs (Toronto, Vancouver) broadly embrace remote/hybrid work; reliable broadband and coworking options support Trey and Sarah's family life.
Canada offers multiple pathways (Express Entry, provincial nominee programs, study-to-work) toward lasting residency with long durations and clear renewal paths.
Canada's CPP/OAS plus universal healthcare provide a solid base. They'd top up with RRSP/TFSA to maintain U.S.-level comfort in Canada.
Canada offers CPP and OAS based on residency/earnings; visa holders who settle long-term can access public pensions, while private savings stay key.
Canada's Ruby market is moderate, concentrated in Toronto/Montreal startups; networking and remote work help Trey secure steady projects.
Canada generally has low crime and safe neighborhoods; exercise normal after-dark caution in larger cities.
Canada offers robust public schooling with French immersion and diverse programs. Some specialty programs may require applications or travel.
Canadian coastal waters stay cool most of the year (about 18-20 C); kids will mostly need wetsuits, with only brief warm spells.
Canada's climate varies by region. Coastal BC stays mild, inland winters demand warm gear and planning.
Canada's urban areas offer open, inclusive sex education and broad acceptance of diverse identities, including LGBTQ+ and non-monogamy.
Canada's universal healthcare and strong safety nets fit Trey/Sarah's needs; good childcare and grants exist, though wait times persist.
Canadian springs swing from warm afternoons to near-freezing mornings, so boots and layers stay ready for school runs.
Canada offers stable, predictable policies and universal healthcare that support your family; expect gradual, peaceful policy shifts.
Canada's pluralist democracy, universal healthcare, and welfare state align with Trey's progressive, regulated-capitalism outlook.
Canada's regulated, SME-friendly market supports startups with grants. Universal healthcare and safety nets reduce family risk.
Canada summers: bursts to ~30°C with nights under 20°C; generally mild, occasional heatwaves.
Canada Express Entry for a family of four: expect 12-18 months to PR; biometrics/medicals add costs.
In Canada (CA), trust in government is generally solid. Some agencies in certain regions may need reputational improvements.
In Canada, corruption is rare and swiftly addressed; issues are typically isolated, so your family can access services without insider favors.
Salaries in Toronto and Vancouver support a solid middle-class lifestyle, but Bay Area-style pay remains distant; blend local work with remote contracts.
In Canada, weekends offer family-friendly options—outdoor skating, parks, and open shops; popular venues may fill quickly, so plan ahead.
Canada's school day generally runs around 8:30-3:00 and many offices support remote/hybrid hours. After-school care fills gaps for a working couple with two kids.
Canada offers 2 weeks vacation plus public holidays; cross-border U.S. visits may require extra time off.
Canada tech firms typically offer 2-3 weeks paid vacation plus holidays. This supports Sarah's downtime and family trips in Canada.
Canada-U.S. ties are close and practical; cross-border travel and culture are common, but politics and privacy debates can color daily chats.
Canada's inclusive, pluralistic self-image matches the family's collaborative values; universal healthcare and safety support a stable life in Canada.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Canada is seen as stable and cooperative by neighbors, helping Trey pitch cross-border US clients from a friendly, reliable base in Canada.
Canada offers Express Entry, PNP, and Start-up visas; online apps and clear criteria, though documentation and funds remain necessary for a family of four.
Canada broadly welcomes US migrants; expat networks aid integration, especially in metro areas, though housing can be tight.
Canada's progressive cities and vast outdoors spark curious family life—civic engagement with parks, arts, and wilderness.
Canada's winters are typically cold with snow. Expect subzero days and the need for strong heating and insulation.
Canada (CA): around 37-38 hour workweeks with occasional crunch. Remote/hybrid options help guard family evenings.
In Canada, workplaces generally respect boundaries with flexible hours and family-friendly policies. Occasional tech crunch periods may require extra hours.
Canada offers strong labour standards, paid leave, and broad union protections that support family stability across provinces. Some gig-sector gaps remain in enforcement.
Canada's winters bring severe cold and snow, causing travel delays and outages; summers are milder but seasonal swings persist.
Canada winters bring deep, multi-week darkness; plan strict routines, light exposure, and occasional sun getaways to keep morale up.
Canada offers several mild months, especially on the coasts. Winter and shoulder seasons require planning, but outdoor time is feasible for much of the year.
Canada's universal healthcare and subsidies help; however urban housing costs and waitlists can still strain lower-income families.
In Canada, housing and childcare strain the budget in major cities. Universal healthcare helps, but saving remains tight for a middle-income family.
Canada (CA) offers universal healthcare and strong public schools for families. Some premium services and clubs exist, but can require planning.

values.key: Spacious Housing Benchmark (2k sq ft Rent)
values.alignmentText: Canada: 2k sq ft rentals exist but inventory is tight in major metros; expect premium rents and broker help.
Canada offers co-housing in major cities with family-friendly programs. New families are welcomed into supportive networks, though spots can be competitive.
Canada generally has polite locals and newcomer support, but friendliness varies by neighborhood. Be proactive in seeking connections and welcoming areas.
Canada is broadly welcoming overall; occasional debates exist, but newcomers can speak languages and share culture openly, and healthcare supports families.
Canada's multicultural model supports US-based tech migrants; most Canadians welcome skilled workers, with only mild stereotypes to navigate.
Canada-wide politeness; most service is courteous and efficient. In major cities (Toronto/Vancouver) expect warm interactions; English is common, French in Quebec.
Canada offers friendly, family oriented communities. In Canadian cities and suburbs, clubs and neighborhood events help your family steadily deepen ties.
Canada's urban centers generally respect personal space. In crowded transit or events, closer contact may occur but cues are easy to read.
Canada's pluralistic, LGBTQ+-friendly culture welcomes honest dialogue. Share concerns directly, but with empathy in Canadian contexts.

Canada's inclusive culture and school programs reduce body-shaming; conversations stay respectful, but occasional boundary setting helps maintain confidence.

Canada’s strong consent culture; in Toronto and Vancouver boundaries are respected, but alcohol-fueled scenes still need mindful check-ins.
Canada's urban centers are largely inclusive; most genders can initiate or decline with minimal stigma, with a few circles showing lingering assumptions.

Canada's urban centers are broadly sex-positive with little moral policing of consenting adults. Our progressive, sex-positive family aligns with a 10.

Canada has strict licensing and safe storage norms; guns exist mainly for hunting, fostering a safety-minded environment for families.
Canada's legalized cannabis framework and strong harm-reduction with universal healthcare create a compassionate, low-risk environment for families.
In Canada (CA), enforcement is proportionate with strong oversight; families rarely witness aggressive drug raids.
In Canada, mass violence is uncommon; authorities share updates transparently and communities feel prepared.
Canada's carceral facilities generally meet international standards. They have active oversight and restorative programs.
Canada has walkable pockets and decent transit; we'll focus on family-friendly neighborhoods with parks and calm streets.

In Canada, urban markets and farmers' stalls offer fresh options, but convenience snacks are still common in schools and events.
Canada has strong global cuisine in major cities like Toronto, Vancouver, Montreal; some specialty ingredients may require a short trip.

values.key: Product Marketing Manager (Games): Education Pipeline Strength
values.alignmentText: Canada has several strong game-marketing degree programs; Ontario/BC schools reliably graduate well-prepared product marketing managers (games) each year.

values.key: Product Marketing Manager (Games): Continuing Education Availability
values.alignmentText: Canada offers regular game-marketing meetups and short courses in Toronto, Montreal, and Vancouver, with solid instructors and good online options.
Canada (CA): PMM (Games) hiring often 1-2 months in major hubs; Toronto and Montreal have strong talent pools and remote options.
Canada PMM (Games) pay is competitive. It trails top NA hubs by ~10–15%, with hybrid roles in Vancouver/Toronto easing family relocation.
Canada PMMs in games primarily use English; French helps in Quebec. Your need for English ubiquity fits, with French as a bonus in Montreal.
Canada-wide: remote and hybrid Product Marketing Manager (Games) roles are normalized with robust async workflows.
